instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01987: What is 820-01987? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.2V5_NAND: What is 2V5_NAND? This is a power rail that powers the SSD that is soldered onto the logic board of Macbook Pro models with a soldered on SSD.
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V8_S5: What is PP1V8_S5? PP1V8_S5 is a 1.8v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .
definitions.RSMRST_L: What is RSMRST_L? RSMRST_L is an abbreviation of PM_RSMRST_L.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Hi, this board had liquid damage around <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> and found a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> that was caused by <CAPACITOR>C9081</CAPACITOR>. Now the board is taking 20v @.08mAmps, can access DFU mode, but get error message when I try to restore it...[ATTACH type="full"]60135[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
That cap is on SSD power supply.
Do you get <SIGNAL>2V5_NAND</SIGNAL>?
You should get all SSD power rails, to complete DFU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> is pulsing... you think the ssd is dead?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Not low value, but there should be stable voltage.
Compare diode mode reading with similar good board.
<CHIP>U9080</CHIP> may be affected by corrosion; you may need to resolder, or change it.
Check all its surrounding components; pay atention to <RESISTOR>R9080</RESISTOR>/81/83.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R9618</RESISTOR> wasn´t in place, I put a resistor there and now is not even pulsing, at <RESISTOR>R9618</RESISTOR> I get a pulse of ,086v PMU can be responsible for that?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Check if other R961x resistors marked with "SSD:2L" are in place.
If not, then remove <RESISTOR>R9618</RESISTOR> too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R9615</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R9617</RESISTOR> are not in place
<RESISTOR>R9616</RESISTOR> is in place
<RESISTOR>R9618</RESISTOR> supposed to be there? isn´t this the enable to <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
As per schematic, your board is in "SSD:4L" configuration.
And enable signal comes directly from <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: So I should remove <RESISTOR>R9618</RESISTOR> and check <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> ? or what can be causing the pulse at <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Remove <RESISTOR>R9618</RESISTOR>, of course.

<SIGNAL>SSD0_VR_P2V5_EN</SIGNAL> pulsing too?
L9020/30 get voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> is pulsing too but <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_PMU_VDDMAIN</SIGNAL> is stable that should create <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
In this case, DFU mode is not possible.
All AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages are required.
To complete it, SSD must get its voltages too.

Check the power sequence using 01055, or 01598 diagrams available on the forum; or logi.wiki webpage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 12,33v but goes a little high when F7000 is in place...
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PPVPCORE_S5</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PP1V_PRIM</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>SSD0_VR_P2V5_PGOOD</SIGNAL> = 0

PBUS = 12.3-12.6
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> = 3.3
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.3

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP0V82_SLPDDR</SIGNAL> = pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = pulsing
PPVDDCPUSRAM_AWAKE = pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SLPDDR</SIGNAL> = pulsing
<SIGNAL>P1V1_SLPDDR_SOCFET_EN</SIGNAL> = pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPDDR</SIGNAL> = pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = pulsing
<SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = pulsing

could it be any of the <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> making the voltages pulse?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Something more affected by corrosion.
Could be a problem with <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, or adiacent component.
You can try to resolder, or change it.

Compare diode mode to ground readings on all its surrounding coils, with similar good board.
